awd_abstract_narration:
The Condensed Matter and Materials Theory and Condensed Matter Physics Programs jointly contribute support to this award.


Non-Technical Summary

Over the last couple of decades, the mathematical concept of "topology" has emerged as a new organizing principle in the science of materials, one that can determine, for example, whether the surface of a solid is metallic or electrically insulating.  Topology refers to global properties that stay the same when a material is perturbed locally.   Topological materials properties remain robust, for instance, against the presence of local imperfections or dirt.  The interactions between electrons in topological materials can be weak or strong, and, because the methods used to study these two classes differ, two communities of scientists have been working on parallel tracks.  The breadth of the field calls for interactions among the communities. This workshop aims to bring together top experts from these two communities to highlight the recent achievements in each area and to provide a forum for cross-talk between the subjects.  Rice University's Rice Center for Quantum Materials will host a two-day workshop on this topic, bringing together top experts and junior researchers from around the globe who probe experimentally candidate materials, develop theoretically the phenomenology of topological materials, and understand the role of strong correlations. The key distinguishing feature of this workshop will be to bring together the weakly and strongly correlated communities interested in topological materials.  This will address an acute need to understand and explore the intersection between topological matter and strong correlations.


Technical Summary

Topological matter in weakly correlated electrons has seen major advances in recent years. Examples include the discovery of "higher-order" topological insulators and their potential experimental realization, Weyl semimetals in magnetically ordered materials, and explorations of topological states of magnons.  Meanwhile, rapid progress has taken place during the last couple of years in exploring electronic topology of strongly correlated systems. Examples include the discovery of strongly correlated Weyl semimetals in heavy-Fermion materials and progress in the search for signatures of topological states in Kondo insulators and iron-based superconductors. For the most part, the two directions have been developing with very limited crosstalk. Now is a particularly opportune time to foster active dialogue between the two communities. The workshop aims to realize this goal by bringing together key players interested in topological materials from the communities of both weak and strong correlations. To enhance the opportunities for crosstalk, it will feature a variety of materials, ranging from weakly interacting systems involving sp-electrons, strongly correlated compounds based on d- and f- electrons, engineered structures including graphene layers, liquid 3He and ultracold atoms. The topics have been chosen with a view to both the level of excitement and the pace of advances that have been made in recent years, as well as by the potential for cross fertilization.

With permission from the speakers, the slides from the talks will be compiled and made available for download in pdf form from the meeting website following the conclusion of the meeting. The slides will include the summary outcomes of the group discussions. The participants will be encouraged to use these as a springboard for graduate education about these problems at their institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Topology has become a key theoretical tool in the analysis of quantum materials. Although topology first came to prominence in 1980s with the discovery of the quantum Hall effect, in the past 15 years it has transformed solid-state physics by providing a general classification framework for how electrons move in materials. This framework predicts robust (“topologically protected”) edge and surface physics that might enable new technological innovations.

At the same time, the quantum materials with the highest disruptive technological potential involve robust high-temperature collective phenomena, such as magnetism or high-temperature superconductivity. Because of the strong electron-electron interactions in so-called “correlated” electron materials, our understanding of how to manipulate or improve the performance of materials such as the high-Tc cuprate superconductors has remained primitive for the past several decades. The successes of the topological revolution have been largely confined to insulators and semimetals, materials in which electron-electron interactions are relatively unimportant. A key question then arises: can topology change our understanding of strongly correlated materials, in a way that might unlock the mechanisms protecting (e.g.) high-temperature superconductivity?

To answer this question, we proposed a workshop on “Topological Materials and Electron Correlations” to bring together the weakly-correlated and strongly-correlated electron communities interested in topology. The workshop would

• highlight the extensive recent developments in each of the two areas, and

• foster interactions between the two communities, which we believe to be both opportune and much-needed.

The topics would be fairly broad-ranging, although the greatest focus will be placed on electronic topology, including Weyl and Dirac semimetals as well as topological insulators and superconductors, from the weak to the strong correlation regime.

This workshop was originally supposed to occur in April 2020, but was postponed multiple times because of the covid-19 pandemic. A virtual component was finally realized: "Part I – Virtual Mini-Workshop, April 26-29, 2021." At this miniworkshop, 5 invited speakers gave one-hour seminars that served both to introduce key concepts, and to provide a broad overview of recent key results. The speakers. The virtual seminars were well attended and stimulated interesting discussions.

The actual in-person workshop, "Part II - RCQM Workshop on Topological Materials and Electron Correlations" was finally held at Rice University, hosted by the Rice Center for Quantum Materials, on Nov. 15-17, 2021. The timing worked out such that the event occurred just after the Delta wave, but before the Omicron surge in the US. As a result, the event was also well attended, and many invited speakers noted that this was the first in-person workshop they had joined in two years.

The workshop aimed to realize the goal of bringing together key players interested in topological materials from the communities of both weak and strong correlations. To enhance the opportunities for crosstalk, it will featured a variety of materials, ranging from weakly-interacting systems involving sp-electrons, strongly correlated compounds based on d- and f- electrons, engineered structures including graphene layers, liquid 3He and ultracold atoms. The main topics included

• Recent developments on weakly correlated topological states with time-reversal

symmetry,

• Weakly interacting topological phases in magnetically ordered systems,

• Topological superconductors,

• Topological states driven by strong correlations,

• Topology and correlations in graphene moiré bands,

• Tuning of topological states,

• Topological physics in diverse materials and broad contexts.

The topics have been chosen with a view to both the level of excitement and the pace of advances that have been made in recent years, as well as by the potential for cross fertilization.

Some of the key research highlights of the workshop included discussion of

(1) Higher-order topological insulators and superconductors. Higher-order topological phases might enable the realization of useful topological boundary modes in a wider array of bulk materials, overcoming materials-specific difficulties that have plagued some of the strong topological platforms developed so far. Amongst materials discussed was Bi4I4, a quasi-1D material that exhibits switchable topological behavior.  

(2) Aspects of topological magnetism. Spin waves in magnetic materials can also exhibit topological band structures, while frustrated magnets are candidate platforms for exotic topological order that could enable a robust form of quantum computation.  

(3) Experimental and theoretical results on the candidate Weyl-topological superconductor UTe2. Topological superconductors are long-sought as platforms for topological quantum computation, but until very recently there was no convincing experimental evidence for candidate materials. Evidence for unconventional spin-triplet pairing was discussed, along with the possible magnetic origin of electron-electron attraction in this material.

(4) Topological aspects of heavy-fermion materials.

Overall the workshop was perceived to have been successful by the attendees, and has stimulated several follow-up programs in the past year. This includes the “2022 RCQM Workshop on Strange Metals and Emergent Phases in Materials and Structures,” held at Rice University on Oct 31—Nov 2, 2022.
